data.title: Gene Kelly’s groundbreaking synchronized dance with his inner conscious, in the “Alter-Ego” number from Cover Girl (1944). Today, CGI would...
data.meta_description: 14K likes, 172 comments - thiswashollywood on March 3, 2021: "Gene Kelly’s groundbreaking synchronized dance with his inner conscious, in the “Alter-Ego” number from Cover Girl (1944). Today, CGI would be used to create the effect, but back then it was much more complicated. “We would have to repeat the camera moves by ourselves, with Gene performing the dance twice to the pre-recorded sound track,” said Stanley Donen, the film’s assistant dance director. “I knew it could be done by having him hit the same spots the second time as he did the first, which Gene could do, and then we could film it by having the camera hit the same marks both times, which I knew I could do.”Superimposition was then used to give the “double” a ghost like quality.".
